question.title: Does Quarkus automatically convert environment variables to the application.properties format?
question.body:
I am working on a Java application that is using a Quarkus configuration set up and referencing the dev profile variables using the syntax:

@ConfigProperty(name = "%dev.example.variable") String exampleVariable;

Originally, the application defined this variable in application.properties, in the form of:

%dev.example.variable=somevalue

However, due to new requirements, this variable needed to be removed from application.properties, but still used in the code under the same name.

To do this, I moved this variable to an .env file, following the correct env variable format listed in the Quarkus Config Guide like this:

_DEV_EXAMPLE_VARIABLE=somevalue

My question is: will Quarkus automatically convert this env variable to the lower case %dev.example.variable format at runtime, so I do not have to rename the references in my code? Or would Quarkus require me to rename all references to _DEV_EXAMPLE_VARIABLE? Is it wise to use the %dev naming convention in the .env file so I can avoid renaming the references?

question_comments.body: Will try this, thanks a lot!

Try removing the %dev. prefix from @ConfigProperty and use just example.variable â€” Quarkus maps EXAMPLE_VARIABLE (env) to example.variable (property) automatically. If that works, you can manage the active profile separately using QUARKUS_PROFILE=dev.
